awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Novel and Fast Open-Source Code for Global Simulation of Stratified Convection and Magnetohydrodynamics of the Sun
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical: 
The goal of this project is to create a unique capability for predicting density-stratified magnetohydrodynamics of the Sun. This research is expected to lay a foundation for developing methods for predicting extreme space weather, e.g. the event of a "super solar flare" followed by an extreme geomagnetic storm. Scientific results of this research can help resolve several contradictory predictions from previous studies of the solar convection zone. The Principal Investigator (PI) will develop and disseminate a powerful open-source software package to the space weather and solar physics communities. The success of predicting severe space weather events has significant societal and economic impacts. PI will design high-order accurate computational algorithms suitable for exascale simulations that can perform a billion billion calculations per second. This software will run on massively parallel distributed-memory computers to predict coupled global and local dynamics of the sun. PI will reach out to K-12 students and demonstrate that science of the sun and high-performance computing are exciting and important to society.  Furthermore, PI will leverage outreach efforts with the High Altitude Observatory of the National Center for Atmospheric Research and other research centers.  This project, thus, serves the national interest as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science and to advance the national welfare.

Technical: 
The goal of this research program is to develop a novel, fully compressible model and an open-source community code for global simulations of the solar convection zone that includes the top near surface shear layer of the Sun. Current leading global simulations use an elastic approximation whose computational domains extend from the base of the solar convection zone and must stop at about 0.96 solar radius, stopping short of the top near surface shear layer where Mach number could reach unity. This research program will create a powerful open-source community code CHORUS++ to simulate magnetohydrodynamics of the solar convection zone.  CHORUS stands for Compressible High-ORder Unstructured-grid Spectral difference code which has been co-developed by the PI for hydrodynamics of the solar convection zone.  CHORUS++ will be equipped with variable mesh resolution capability to focus on targeted regions of interests. A fast local time-stepping algorithm will be designed and equipped for CHORUS++ for long-period time integration on massively parallel computers. These technical accomplishments can accelerate the original CHORUS code by a factor over 100.  The PI will conduct a series of global simulations of magnetohydrodynamics of the solar convection zone with unprecedented resolutions for predicting the differential rotation, meridional circulation, giant cells, and super-granulation of the sun.

por.por_cntn:
Major Outcome I of this project is the CHORUS++ code which is over 10 times faster than the original CHORUS code for simulating thermal convection in the outer one-third radius of the Sun. Specifically, this project accomplished two major improvements over the Compressible High-ORder Unstructured Spectral-difference (CHORUS) code published in 2015 in Journal of Computational Physics by Wang, Liang and Miesch.  The first improvement lies in the integration of the high-order spectral difference method with a boundary-conforming transfinite mapping on a cubed-sphere grid thus ensuring exact geometric representations of spherical surfaces on arbitrarily sparse grids.  The second improvement is on the adoption of higher-order elements (p5 or p6) in CHORUS++ instead of p2 or p3 elements for the original CHORUS code. CHORUS++ enables high-fidelity simulations of the solar convection zone using p5 or p6 elements on very coarse grids. CHORUS++ is expected to be published in Physics of Fluids (2023) after receiving positive reviews from the journal in June 2023.
Major Outcome II of this project is the creation of the SDDC algorithm.  The high-order spectral difference method with divergence cleaning (SDDC) is successfully designed for accurate simulations of both ideal and resistive magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) on curved unstructured grids. The SDDC algorithm is suitable for modeling and simulation of global solar dynamo. The implementation of SDDC in CHORUS++ is ongoing. The two-dimensional SDDC algorithm was published in Chen & Liang (2022), Astrophysical Journal, Vol 932. Subsequently, an extension of SDDC to solve Hall MHD equations was published in Hankey, Chen and Liang (2023), Northeast Journal Complex Systems, Vol 5.  
 
This project has been used to support the completion of three Ph.D. theses including 1. Jingjing Yang, A High-Order Adaptive Mesh Refinement Method for Shock Capturing and Magnetohydrodynamics. Ph.D. dissertation, The George Washington University, 2018; 2. Xiaoliang Zhang, CHORUS-MHD Code for Solar and Planetary Magnetohydrodynamics. Ph.D. dissertation, The George Washington University, 2019;  and 3. Kuangxu Chen, High-Order Accurate Simulations of Compressible MHD Dynamo on Unstructured Grids, Ph.D. thesis, Clarkson University, 2023
The project also supported research activities of three different undergraduate students, two of whom will continue their graduate studies under the advice of the PI. Undergraduate research led to a journal article: Hankey, Chen and Liang (2023) published in Northeast Journal of Complex Systems for extending the SDDC algorithm for solving Hall MHD equations. 
In addition, this project also involved three high-school students in learning numerical methods for solving nonlinear partial differential equations. Two high-school students started their college education in the STEM field.
